abstracts.cdata!:
With a population of more than 60
            million and an average per capita income of $100 a year,
            Ethiopia is one of the world's poorest countries. More
            than 70 percent of the country was susceptible to malaria,
            and tuberculosis was the major cause of hospital-registered
            death. In 1996, the Social Rehabilitation and Development
            Fund Project was created to help remote communities address
            these tragedies, backed by a commitment from the World Bank
            to finance half of the project's 240 million dollars
            total cost. Since then, the project has enabled 600,000
            children, 49 percent of them girls, to attend school. Four
            million people now have easier access to health and
            sanitation facilities.
